thread.title: Justin Trudeau pitches to voters in Conservative heartland
thread.title_full: Justin Trudeau pitches to voters in Conservative heartland

author: CBC News
title: Justin Trudeau pitches to voters in Conservative heartland
text:
Justin Trudeau pitches to voters in Conservative heartland Liberal leader addresses political schism between Western and Central Canada on campaign's last day CBC News Posted: Oct 18, 2015 12:45 PM ET Last Updated: Oct 18, 2015 4:07 PM ET Trudeau to Alberta: "This place is important to me" 1:39 Related Stories Justin Trudeau hounded by tough questions on Dan Gagnier's departure 
Liberal Leader Justin Trudeau is making a direct appeal to voters in the Conservative heartland on the final day of the federal election campaign. 
"I've been coming out to Alberta for years with a message that this place is important to me, that this place matters deeply," he said to supporters in Edmonton. Election night: Follow CBC's live results page 
"It's a message that I'm proud to deliver here with a big smile, as a Liberal, as a Trudeau, and as a Quebecer," he declared, underlining the significance of the party's decision to hold its final events in Alberta. 
A political gap has existed between Western Canada and Central Canada since the days of former prime minister Pierre Trudeau. That sense of alienation harboured by the Prairie provinces was a major driver of Conservative Leader Stephen Harper's move into politics. 
The younger Trudeau, who's running for re-election in Montreal, addressed that national divide today. Liberal Leader Justin Trudeau was in Edmonton and Calgary for part of the final day of the election campaign. His message to supporters? Alberta matters. (Paul Chiasson/Canadian Press) 
"You see, every part of this country matters. People in Quebec need to know that Alberta matters, that our country needs Alberta to succeed. But so, too, do Quebecers need to be reminded that our country needs them to engage too." Western resources, eastern votes 
Trudeau, who has been drawing large crowds of supporters in the days leading up to Monday's vote, hopes the election will help the Liberals find their way out of the political wilderness in Alberta. 
The party hasn't had an MP in the province since Anne McLellan lost her Edmonton seat in 2006. 
The Liberal leader repeated his message in Calgary. 
"I will never use western resources to try and buy eastern votes," he said. 
The Liberals have been riding high in the polls in the final weeks of the campaign. 
According to CBC's Poll Tracker, a number of polls suggest election day will go to the Grits , installing Trudeau as Canada's next prime minister. However, favourable polls today don't rule out the possibility that the Conservatives could eke out more seats tomorrow. 
Trudeau winds down his campaign in British Columbia later today, before flying back to Montreal. Trudeau says he won't use western resources to buy eastern votes 2:29 With files from The Canadian Press
